metadata.name: The Pilgrims Who Never Arrived (1/1)
metadata.description: [1/2] In July 2013, an Alvia high-speed train crashed in the city of Santiago de Compostela (Galicia) in northern Spain. It was the evening before the annual festival celebrating the city's namesake, Santiago, or St. James in English. The train was the last one arriving before dinner that night and the place where the crash occurred was the last major curve on the line, after the last of many tunnels through the Galician mountains, before the station and waiting relatives. The 81 people who died suddenly were only two or three minutes away from family, friends, loved ones, dinner, wine, celebration, beauty and joy. It was not to be. In the days after the tragedy, mourners and wellwishers left traditional walking sticks and flowers on the gate of the city's 13th Century cathedral, the final destination for the thousands of pilgrims who each year walk the hundreds of kilometres of the Camino, or St. James' Way, all across the north of Spain, in memory of those who that night just didn't quite make it. "What we have loved, we never lose", read one of the notes.
